course_title: Religion & Contemporary Experience: LGBTQ Religion & Spirituality

This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement: - Theme.
Rather than ask what religious texts, teachers, and traditions say about sexuality and gender, this course will focus on what LGBTQ-identified people have had to say about religion and spirituality, exploring their cultural agency, creativity, and power. Here are some examples of topics we will explore: lesbian feminist embodied goddess spirituality; representation and veneration of queer and transgender people as sacred figures ("saints"); the Radical Faeries movement; the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence order of "queer nuns"; spiritual dimensions of Native American and First Nations "Two-Spirit" identities; LGBTQ-affirming expressions of Pentecostal Christianity; hijra and kinnar identities in South Asia and their connections with Hinduism and Islam; the Taoist deity Tu'er Shen and his worship in Taiwan; queer and transgender interpretations of scriptures and myths.
course_description: Religion and contemporary issues of human existence, the role of religion in politics and international conflicts, or the nature of contemporary religious movements such as fundamentalism.
